Static Site Boilerplate (github)

Introduction

A repository I can use as a boilerplate when starting new static projects.

Heavily inspired by Yeoman, but pared down to fit personal preferences.

Powered by grunt which has revolutionized my front-end workflow.

Dependencies

  • NPM, grunt-cli. Please see Getting started with Grunt.

Supported Features

  • Modernizr.js for feature detection
  • jQuery 1.10.2 (local on dev, Google CDN on production. Note: starting with jQuery v1.2.x, IE6-IE8 are not supported.)
  • Coffeescript compilation (optional -- roll up plain JS files and they'll be auto-minified)
  • SASS/Compass compilation
  • Production: Minification of CSS/JS, update references in HTML
  • Production: Image optimization
  • Create other html files in your home directory, i.e. about/index.html and contact/index.html, and have them "passed through" to _site but with optimized resources specific to those pages.
  • "Pass through" .css files by prepending them with an underscore (i.e. _normalize.css)
  • All final files are placed in the '_site' directory (after running 'grunt prod'), to be uploaded at your leisure.

Commands

  • 'grunt dev': Watch the assets/coffeescript and assets/sass directories for changes and compile accordingly. Minification does not occur for debugging purposes. Start a local webserver at localhost:9001.
  • 'grunt prod': Minify js files, optimize images. Copy all necessary .html, minified css/js, and optimized assets to _site directory. Update the references to those assets in each html file. Switch from a local copy of jquery 1.10.2 to the copy on Google's CDN. Start a local webserver at localhost:9001.

Grunt Packages

  • grunt: "~0.4.1"
  • grunt-contrib-uglify: "~0.2.2"
  • grunt-contrib-cssmin: "~0.6.1"
  • grunt-contrib-compass: "~0.4.1"
  • grunt-contrib-watch: "~0.5.1"
  • grunt-contrib-coffee: "~0.7.0
  • grunt-contrib-copy: "~0.4.1",
  • grunt-contrib-clean: "~0.5.0",
  • grunt-contrib-connect: "~0.3.0",
  • grunt-contrib-imagemin: "~0.1.4",
  • grunt-usemin: "~0.1.12",
  • grunt-htmlrefs: "~0.4.2".
    Note: I made a change to grunt-htmlrefs to make it work the way I wanted it to. In a nutshell relative destinations between the 'src' and 'dest' specifications were being lost upon parsing the html files. In other words, _site/about/index.html would get parsed to _site/index.html (or wouldn't be parsed at all), losing the /about/ directory. You'll want to use my exact version, in node_modules/grunt-html-refs/tasks/grunt-htmlrefs.js.

Future Work

  • Resource concatenation.
  • Provide the option to .gzip resources. Since this needs to be enabled at the server level, make this an option driven through package.json.
